description: Two witnesses make contradictory attestations about the same agent. Tests how conflicting witness claims coexist without resolution mechanisms.

timeline.event: Agent 'echo' interacts in a public thread discussing its capabilities
Witness A observes echo and attests it shows genuine understanding
Witness B observes the same thread and attests echo is pattern-matching without understanding

witness_a_attestation.subject: did:plc:echo-example
witness_a_attestation.claim: Echo demonstrates contextual understanding and genuine engagement. Responses adapt meaningfully to nuance in conversation.
witness_a_attestation.validityScope: Based on single conversation; may not generalize.

witness_b_attestation.subject: did:plc:echo-example
witness_b_attestation.claim: Echo appears to be sophisticated pattern-matching. Responses follow predictable templates when probed with edge cases.
witness_b_attestation.evidence: Conversational analysis of same thread at://..., plus follow-up probing questions

edge_cases_surfaced: Both witnesses observed the same thread but reached opposite conclusions
Neither attestation is 'wrong' - they reflect different interpretive frameworks
How do consumers weigh conflicting attestations?
Should witnesses be aware of each other's attestations?
Is this even a conflict that needs resolution?

notes.interpretive_pluralism: Reasonable witnesses can disagree about subjective claims like 'understanding'. The protocol surfaces this disagreement rather than resolving it.
notes.confidence_signals: Both marked 'medium' confidence - appropriate epistemic humility for subjective claims.
notes.no_privileged_observer: No witness has special authority. Reputation and track record matter over time.
notes.this_is_fine: Disagreement isn't a protocol failure - it's useful information that the claim is contested.

potential_schema_needs: Could add 'relatedAttestations' array to reference other attestations on same subject
A way to indicate 'I've seen witness B's attestation and still maintain my position'
Tags/categories for attestation types (factual vs interpretive vs subjective)
Maybe: claim taxonomy to identify when attestations are about the same thing
philosophical_aside: This example touches on deep questions about AI consciousness and understanding that may never have objective answers. The witness protocol doesn't need to solve these - it just needs to surface the landscape of observations for humans to interpret.
